org.nosco
Class ThreadContext

java.lang.Object
  org.nosco.ThreadContext

public class ThreadContext
extends java.lang.Object

This class is used to control thread-based context operations.   For instance you can start, commit and roll back transactions using this API.   All operations are specific to both the DataSource and the current thread.   Typical use would be like the following (where db.DEFAULT is the data source generated by the CodeGenerator or pulled from a Query instance): 

   ThreadContext.start(db.DEFAULT);
   SomeClass x = SomeClass.ALL.get(SomeClass.ID.eq(123));
   x.setName("my new name");
   x.update();
   doSomeOtherWork();
   SomeClass.ALL.where(SomeClass.ID.eq(456)).deleteAll();
   ThreadContext.commit(db.DEFAULT);
If any of the SQL calls failed (throwing a SQLException), the transaction would be rolled back.   Note that database calls in doSomeOtherWork() will also be within this transaction (as long as they're still within the same thread).

Author:
Derek Anderson

setDatabaseOverride

public static void setDatabaseOverride(javax.sql.DataSource ds,
                                       java.lang.String oldName,
                                       java.lang.String newName)
All extracted schemas contain the database names they're extracted from.   Setting this will cause all access to mydatabase.my_table to myotherdatabase.my_table.   (applied on a per-thread basis)   Note that in this context database means the database instance, not the database server.

Parameters:
ds -
oldName -
newName -

getDatabaseOverride

public static java.lang.String getDatabaseOverride(javax.sql.DataSource ds,
                                                   java.lang.String name)
All extracted schemas contain the database names they're extracted from.   This will look up any name overrides set with setDatabaseOverride(), returning the original name is no overrides have been set.  Note that in this context database means the database instance, not the database server.

Parameters:
ds -
name -
Returns:
